header.title: Table of Questions (Part 7)
authors: Based on the teachings of Isaac Luria (ARI)

central_thesis: The document serves as a specialized glossary defining the precise technical vocabulary of Lurianic Kabbalah. Its implicit central thesis is to delineate the intricate cosmic processes of emanation, rectification (Tikun), and the dynamic interplay between spiritual Lights (Orot) and Vessels (Kelim) across the four worlds, with a particular focus on the 'back' (Achoraim) and 'front' (Panim) aspects of the Partzufim. It details the mechanisms of spiritual growth (Gadlut), diminution (Katnut), and the constant interaction with opposing forces (Klipot), providing the conceptual framework for understanding the Kabbalistic operative system.

structure_content.chapter_title: Table of Questions for the Meaning of the Words
structure_content.summary: This section is a glossary presented as a series of ninety questions, each followed by a detailed answer defining a specific technical term or concept within Lurianic Kabbalah. The entries are numbered sequentially and often include cross-references to other 'Items' or to specific sections within the 'Ohr Pnimi' commentary, indicating its role as an explanatory resource for a larger Kabbalistic text.

key_concepts.definition: A state of correction for Partzufim lacking GAR de Hochma, where they are rectified by receiving Ohr de Achoraim de Bina (Ohr Awzen, Bina de Rosh). It signifies that their hinder parts were inward, enabling correction in the absence of full higher light.

A correction applied in ZON (Zachar and Nukva) that qualifies the Kelim de Panim de Nukva to receive Ohr Panim. This involves the Zachar dispensing He'arat Hassadim through his Achor (back part) to the Nukva's Panim (front part), enabling her to tolerate He'arat Hochma.

Refers to the Orot de Panim (front lights) of the Zachar when they pass to the Nekeva (female Partzuf) through her Achoraim (back parts). They clothe in the cover of her Ohr Achoraim, causing them to diminish and lessen in value, not shining in their fullest measure.
Always regarded as Behinat Kelim (vessels), encompassing both the letters of the alphabet and the letters comprising the Holy Names.

Comprises the Reshimot (reminiscences) of the Eser Sefirot de Gadlut (ten Sefirot of Greatness) from the four Komot (levels) that were in Behinat Roshim (head aspects) for the four Melachim DHGT (Kings of Daat, Hod, Gevurah, Tifferet), along with the Behinat MAN received from Yesod de AK (Nekuda Abba took and Vav Ima took). These are understood as fallen from Behinat Rosh de AVI (Abba and Ima) to Behinat Guf (body aspect).

Achieved when ZA (Z'eir Anpin) possesses both Achoraim de Ima in his HGT (Chesed, Gevurah, Tifferet) shining through the Chazeh (chest), and Achoraim de Yesod de Abba in his NHY (Netzah, Hod, Yesod) shining from the Chazeh downward. This completeness requires obtaining Hey Hassadim from Zivug Panim be Panim de AVI.

The sustenance drawn by the Klipot (shells/forces of evil). Originally complete evil, the Klipot became sustained after the Breaking of the Vessels, when mixed good and evil fell into them. Remnants of Orot became 'Minute Light' that shines and sustains the Klipot. Sin, particularly of Etz ha Daat, or human sin, further causes proliferation of sustenance to the Sitra Achra (other side).

The process necessary when parts of Behina Dalet (the fourth, lowest emanation) are mixed within a Kli (vessel), rendering it unfit to receive the Ohr Elyon (highest light). Scrutinies involve sorting out and separating these Behina Dalet parts to qualify the Kli for the Ohr Elyon.

Refers to Mochin de Abba (lights/consciousness from Abba), specifically He'arat Hochma (illumination of Wisdom). It denotes a state of spiritual growth and completion, where Ohr Hochma appears in the Partzuf and attains its fullness.

These describe different states of the Eser Sefirot (ten emanations). If their Atzmut (essence) is purely Ohr de Hassadim (Light of Mercy), they are called Hey Hassadim (HGT NH). If they are in Behinot Gevurot (aspects of Severity), meaning He'arat Hochma without Hassadim, they are KHB ZON. If they have both Atzmut of Hassadim and He'arat Hochma, they are Hey Hassadim HGT NH; if they lack Hassadim but only He'arat Hochma, they are Hey Gevurot HGT NH.

The act of 'raising Masculine Waters,' which means inducing a Zivug (spiritual coupling). This process is initiated by the Nekeva, often in a state of Achoraim de Ima (back-part consciousness), through the compelling force of ZON (Z'eir Anpin and Nukva) connected to Bina. Raising MAN causes the Nekeva to shift from Achoraim to Panim, receiving He'arat Hochma through a Panim be Panim mating.

The state of 'face-to-face cleaving' when AVI (Abba and Ima) attain Komat Keter (the Crown level). In this state, Hochma de Abba bestows directly upon Hochma de Ima, and Ima is entirely cleaved to Abba, becoming Behinat Ohr Hochma in a state of Hishtavut Tzura (equivalence of form). A lesser form, 'Some Dvekut de Panim be Panim,' occurs with Zivug de Binot.

Meaning 'One Line,' this describes the state before Tikun Kavim (Rectification of Lines) when ZAT (Z'eir Anpin and Nukva) existed in a single, undifferentiated line, one spiritual degree below the other.

Refers to a protective covering over Ohr Hochma. One aspect is 'The Wall of HGT,' formed by Achoraim de Ima, present in HGT (Chesed, Gevurah, Tifferet) up to the Chazeh. The other is Achoraim de NHY (Netzah, Hod, Yesod) from Yesod Abba, which covers Ohr Hochma when there is no Ohr de Hassadim. In Katnut (smallness), both ZA and Nukva use the HGT wall, half for each, as Nukva's NHY wall is withheld due to fear of external gripping forces.

A pivotal event in Lurianic Kabbalah, signifying when a Kli (vessel) becomes disqualified from receiving the Ohr (light) and is therefore considered 'broken.' This event leads to the scattering of 'Nitzotzot' (sparks) and the descent of Kelim into the Klipot.

practical_system.description: While not a direct step-by-step magical manual, this glossary provides the essential theoretical framework for a highly sophisticated system of operative Kabbalah. The practitioner, armed with these precise definitions, understands the cosmic 'machinery' by which spiritual rectification (Tikun) occurs. The goal is to consciously align one's own internal spiritual 'Partzufim' and 'Kelim' with the higher spiritual worlds, moving from states of 'Katnut' (spiritual smallness) to 'Gadlut' (spiritual greatness). This involves initiating spiritual couplings ('Zivugim') through the 'Raising MAN' (Masculine Waters) of one's desires and intentions, facilitating the descent of 'Ohr Panim' (face-front light) and achieving 'Dvekut Panim be Panim' (face-to-face cleaving) with the Divine. The detailed understanding of 'Achoraim' (back parts), 'Kelim' (vessels), 'Orot' (lights), 'Masach' (screen), and the identification and purification from 'Klipot' (forces of evil) through 'Scrutinies' (purifications) are all critical for consciously participating in this complex process of inner and outer world transformation. The definitions here serve as the intellectual 'operating manual' for the spiritual technology described in Lurianic texts.
tools: Kelim (spiritual vessels, the receptacles for divine light)
Masach (spiritual screen, limiting and regulating the flow of light)
Reshimot (spiritual reminiscences or programs for rectification)
The practitioner's consciousness and purified desires (Kavvanah and MAN)
rituals: Kavvanah (intensive intention and meditation during prayer and study)
Raising MAN (conscious arousal of desire/intention to draw down higher lights)
Torah study (especially Zohar and Lurianic texts, which themselves are seen as vehicles for Tikkun)
Recitation of specific prayers and blessings (activating specific Partzufim and Zivugim)

relevant_quotes.text: Otiot are always Behinat Kelim, both the Otiot of the alphabet and the Otiot of the Holy Names, and we must always remember that.

A Grip is like an Anaf that grips to the tree and sucks its Shefa through its holding place. Similarly, the Klipa grips the place of lack that she finds in the Kedusha. This place is her tube by which she sucks her entire force and sustenance, according to the measure of dearth that she finds there.
When the Kli was disqualified from receiving the Ohr, it is considered that the Kli broke.

Etz ha Daat was mixed with good and evil. It means that Behina Dalet, called evil, was mixed there. After Adam ha Rishon had eaten from Etz ha Daat, he lost his first Guf, which was all good, and a Guf from Behinat Mishcha de Hivia (Aramaic: lit. The serpent's skin) came to him, mixed of good and evil too. For this reason he is unfitting to clothe the Kedusha, except through purification and separation of the evil from the Guf.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is profoundly relevant to the study and practice of Lurianic Kabbalah, particularly its operative aspects. It functions as an indispensable lexicon, providing precise definitions for the highly abstract and nuanced terminology that underpins the entire Lurianic cosmological and soteriological system. For a practitioner, understanding concepts like 'Achor be Achor' (back-to-back rectification) or 'Raising MAN' (the initiate's role in spiritual coupling) is not merely academic; it clarifies the energetic flows, the states of consciousness, and the precise intentions (Kavvanot) required to engage with the processes of Tikkun. The detailed explanations of 'Ohr' (Light), 'Kelim' (Vessels), 'Partzufim' (spiritual personae), and their configurations (Panim/Achoraim) are crucial for navigating the symbolic landscape of ascent and descent, enabling conscious participation in the restoration of cosmic harmony and the elevation of sparks from the 'Breaking of the Vessels'. The text also highlights the mechanics of the 'Klipot' (shells of evil) and 'Scrutinies' (purifications), providing a map for the internal and external struggles inherent in the mystical path.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this text is advanced students and practitioners of Lurianic Kabbalah. It assumes a foundational understanding of primary Kabbalistic concepts and delves into highly technical and intricate details. It is particularly valuable for those studying the seminal works of Rabbi Isaac Luria (the ARI) and the extensive commentaries by Rabbi Yehuda Ashlag (Baal HaSulam) and Rabbi Baruch Ashlag (RABASH), such as 'Talmud Eser Sefirot' and 'Ohr Pnimi,' from which these definitions likely originate. The text serves as a specialized reference for clarifying ambiguities and deepening comprehension of the subtle spiritual mechanics described in these profound mystical texts.
